content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The slide displays multiple sections of tissue, predominantly adipose tissue containing several lymph nodes. I can clearly identify at least four lymph nodes of varying sizes. They appear very cellular (dark purple). The lymph node on the top left is large, well-circumscribed, and uniformly dark, which is suspicious. The one in the center-bottom is also hypercellular and has an irregular shape. The tissue fragments on the right contain smaller lymphoid aggregates and areas of hemorrhage.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into this area because it is the largest and most well-preserved lymph node on the slide (the first lymph node from the top-left). Its uniformly dark, hypercellular appearance is highly abnormal and raises strong suspicion for complete replacement by tumor, as opposed to a reactive process which often preserves some architecture. It's crucial to examine such suspicious nodes at high power to look for metastatic tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining each lymph node to check for metastasis. I chose to zoom into this central lymph node because its irregular contour and non-uniform, mottled basophilic staining at low power are suspicious features. These features suggest that the normal lymph node architecture might be effaced or replaced by an infiltrating process, such as a metastatic tumor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, the normal lymph node architecture is almost completely effaced. It is replaced by a dense infiltrate of atypical cells with dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm. These cells are arranged in poorly formed, crowded, and fused glandular structures, characteristic of an adenocarcinoma. The morphology is consistent with metastatic colorectal carcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node, extensively involved by metastasis.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see residual lymphoid tissue (dense sheets of small, dark, round cells) being infiltrated by malignant glands. These glands are irregular in shape and size, arranged in a back-to-back and cribriform pattern, and are composed of atypical epithelial cells with enlarged, hyperchromatic nuclei. This morphology is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
